pages:
STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 7, 2023
MATTHEW THOMAS KUZMA
KALAMAZOO COUNTY DHHS
427 E Alcott St,
Kalamazoo, MI, 49001-6170
RE: License#: CP390201215
Dear MATTHEW THOMAS KUZMA:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
1/23/2023-1/26/2023. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member shall not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker
for purposes of providing direct services in foster care,
independent living, adoption, or post adoption services or
a combination thereof.
2 of 14 direct foster care case carrying staff are not within caseload compliance.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
R 400.12213 Record Management.
An agency shall do all of the following with respect to
maintenance of required records:
(b) Keep each record in a uniform fashion.
9 of 11 open foster care & independent living case files reviewed contained several
documents that were uploaded the week prior to the audit despite the documents
having been due or completed throughout the period under review. The files are
not being maintained uniformly as prescribed per FOM 722-05.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement
(b) If the child is not returned to a parent, then the reason
why that’s not possible
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with a
relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible
(d) Consideration of the factors identified R 400.12404(4)
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s
age, appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand,

which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as to
why the change is necessary
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and the courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
(h) The child’s new location and address
7 of 11 total open foster care & independent living case files reviewed did not
contain documentation of all the required information, which would be confirmed
through the timely completion of the DHHS 69, Action Summary form.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as FOM 722-08E
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
required information was provided to the caregiver timely, which would be
confirmed through the caregiver signature on the DHHHS-3307 and the timely
upload of the DHHS-3762 as well as a coordinating case contact documenting
these were provided.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
1 of 11 total open foster care & independent living case files (1 of 1 total ISP's)
reviewed contained an Initial Service Plan completed outside of the required
timeframe by 2 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
2 of 11 total open foster care & independent living case files (2 of 18 total USPs)
reviewed contained updated service plans completed late by 1 and 2 days,
respectively.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
R400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all
of the following information in the case record
within 30 calendar days of termination of its
services:
(a) The reason for the termination
(b) The youth’s new location
(c) A summary of the services provided during care
and the needs that remain to be met
(d) Provision for any follow-up services
1 of 2 closed independent living case files reviewed did not contain documentation
of all required information. This information could be captured on the DHHS-69
Action Summary for case closure.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Policy requirements
except for the following:
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or

no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
5 of 11 total open foster care & independent living case files reviewed did not
contain documentation that all required FTMs were held. The majority of the
missing meetings were required for service plan development and placement
changes.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
FOM 722-06H CASE CONTACTS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face
contact in the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If
there is more than one caregiver, such as a primary and
secondary caregiver, the caseworker must have a face-
to-face contact with the secondary caregiver in the home
at least once each quarter.
1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
required face to face meeting with the youth were completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY
SIGNATURES
SUPERVISOR APPROVAL
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan
within 14 calendar days of the report date.
3 of 11 total open foster care and independent living files (3 of 19 service plans)
reviewed contained service plans that were not approved within the required
timeframe. The approvals were 6, 20, and 26 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as FOM 722-09
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
SIGNATURES

Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan
when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures
pages into the electronic case record within 30 days
of the report date.
6 of 11 total open foster care and independent living files (8 of 19 service plans)
reviewed contained PATPs with either late or missing signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.

For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child/youth's placement date to the following:
Foster care provider.
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties
is documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
6 of 8 total open foster care case files did not contain all required updated and
signed medical passports.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/8/2022, CAP Approved 9/23/2022
Interim Inspection Report 11/19/2021, CAP Approved 12/9/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Obtaining comments from foster care workers who have worked with the
family for foster home annual/renewal assessments. One assessment
reviewed indicated that attempts were made to obtain the required comments,
but no response was received, despite the worker being employed by the
same agency.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Additional oversight and monitoring regarding timely document completion
and uploading.
• Documenting face to face contacts for youth who are being visited by
courtesy/ICPC workers.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan was submitted in response to licensing renewal inspection
report dated 9/8/2022 and was approved on 9/23/2022. Compliance with that CAP
has been partially maintained as evidenced by 6 of the 17 violations addressed in
the 2022 CAP being resolved and not repeated this inspection. Of the 12 violations
established during this inpection, 1 is a new citation and 11 are repeat violations.
Compared to the 2022 inspection, the percentage of incidents of each repeat
violation has decreased siginificantly regarding caseload compliance, face to face
contacts, FTM's held, and PATP signatures. The percentage of incidents of non
compliance has remained the same for providing information to caregivers at
placement/re-placement and increased slightly regarding medical passports, service
plan approval, and service plan timeliness. The precentage of incidents of non-
compliance reagrding documenting information required at placement/replacement
as well as file maintenance increased significantly; however it is noted that, in 2022,
the agency was cited for falsifying documents, many of which were the documents
for placement/replacement. During this year's inspection, several documents were
completed and/or uploaded outside of the required timeframe, resulting in the file
maintenance and the placement/replacement documentation citation, but none of
those documents were altered or backdated which is likely the cause of increased
number of late/missing documents. Overall, the agency has demonstrated
implementation of the 2022 CAP and has demonstrated action toward improving
compliance.
Financial overview: No financial concerns were identified.
Chief Administrator Assessment: The chief administrator assessment was
submitted and reviewed on 1/23/2023. The chief administrator identified issues
related to staffing resulting in areas on non-compliance. The Chief Administrator
indicated that the agency has made progress in hiring additional staffing, reducing
caseloads, and providing oversight; however, they are not yet fully staffed and have
experienced a 100% turnover in administration as well as worker turnover which has
resulted in the previously approved CAP not yet meeting its full effectiveness.
Interviews – The staff interviewed all reported being supported by their peers and
immediate superiors. The foster care workers reported that a reduction in caseload
sizes has improved their ability to complete required tasks. They all expressed that
there have been challenges related to worker and leadership turnover, but they feel
encouraged by the direction the current leadership is taking.

Description of Agency Walkthrough: The agency was observed to have sufficient
office space and equipment. Case files are stored in a manner that is secure by
utilizing a file room that can only be accessed by key cards, preventing unauthorized
access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified 1 safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert: The roof was leaking in one of the bedrooms where a child was placed
in an unlicensed relative home.
Resolution: Foster Care and Licensing staff confirmed on 12/15/2022 that no
children were sleeping or spending any time in the bedroom with the leak. The foster
care worker is assisting the family with obtaining FIG funds to make the needed
repairs.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
January 27, 2023
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 30, 2023
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
